title: RL32086
content: In the early 19th century, the federal government started developing labor standards for its workforce, but much of the work was done by private contractors who were not subject to these standards. Public work was awarded to the lowest bidder without considering working conditions. Regulation of wages, hours, and child labor was seen as unconstitutional and left to local governments. Private contractors often sought contracts and then subcontracted to firms with the lowest costs, cutting labor expenses by hiring cheap, temporary workers. This led to poor working conditions and low wages, as government regulations did not apply to subcontractors. This informal alliance between procurement officers and low-wage employers allowed private contractors to gain a competitive edge by paying less for labor. An alliance between procurement officers and low-wage employers aimed to cut costs by keeping wages low, leading to poor working conditions. Government's failure to address abusive practices sacrificed its role as a model employer. Government could set standards for its employees and public procurement, defining fairness and professionalism in the construction industry. The construction industry faced challenges with assessing contractor and worker credentials, leading to some firms bidding above their expertise level. Itinerant contractors would enter local markets, sometimes delivering excellent work but also being labeled as "fly-by-night operators." Outside firms came under scrutiny in the 1920s, especially as the Great Depression approached. During the 1920s, the construction industry faced challenges as the Great Depression loomed, leading to issues of fairness in wages and competition between local and outside contractors. The federal construction program aimed to provide jobs for local workers but often outside contractors with low-wage crews would underbid and move on, frustrating efforts to help distressed communities. The impact of public contracting activity during this time period requires further exploration. In 1931, the Davis-Bacon Act was passed as an emergency measure to ensure that construction workers were paid the prevailing rate of wages for similar work on federal projects. The Act aimed to end wage-based competition from unreliable contractors, stabilize the local contracting community, and protect workers from unfair practices. The Davis-Bacon Act of 1931 aimed to stabilize the local contracting community and protect workers from exploitation. However, problems quickly arose, leading to oversight hearings and President Hoover issuing Executive Order No. 5778. In 1934, the Copeland "anti-kickback" Act was adopted to address issues of contractors demanding rebates from employees. The Davis-Bacon Act of 1931 was amended in 1935 to address issues such as contractors fragmenting work to avoid coverage thresholds, extending coverage to public works, and implementing penalties for violators. The amendments also required Davis-Bacon contracts to specify minimum wages for laborers and mechanics. The Davis-Bacon Act of 1931 was amended in 1935 to establish pre-determined wage rates for laborers and mechanics. The amendments added enforcement provisions and integrated Davis-Bacon requirements into federal procurement policy. In the early 1960s, Congress reviewed the act and made changes to provide for independent review of wage rate determinations. In 1964, Secretary of Labor Willard Wirtz established a Wage Appeals Board within DOL, bypassing Congress. The Davis-Bacon Act was amended to include fringe benefits in 1964. The act has been a topic of debate in Congress since the 1960s, with instances of suspension by Presidents Nixon and Bush. President Clinton restored the act in 1992 after it was suspended by President Bush. President George W. Bush suspended the Davis-Bacon Act on September 8, 2005, to aid in Hurricane Katrina recovery efforts in specific states. The act was reinstated on November 8, 2005. The General Accounting Office criticized the act and its administration over the years, leading to debates and proposed administrative changes. The Davis-Bacon Act has been a subject of extended litigation and debate since the Carter and Reagan Administrations. The economic impact of the act remains unresolved, along with disputes over prevailing wage rate determinations and other administrative aspects. Government contracts for goods have historically faced complaints of abuse, with efforts to prevent sweatshop conditions and profiteering during World War I. During World War I, reformers fought to protect workers from exploitation on the home front. Post-war, the government hesitated to interfere with labor practices of the private sector, leading to collaboration with firms cutting wages. In the early 1930s, the Roosevelt Administration pushed for reforms, resulting in the National Industrial Recovery Act (NIRA) in 1933. The NIRA aimed to establish fair competitive practices, including minimum wage and overtime pay requirements, but was later declared unconstitutional in 1935. The Roosevelt Administration sought to salvage labor standards provisions after the NIRA was declared unconstitutional in 1935. Labor Secretary Frances Perkins drafted bills for establishing labor standards under federal contracts, leading to the Fair Labor Standards Act in 1938. Legislation mandating labor standards in federal contract production was introduced by Senator David Walsh and Representative Arthur Healey in 1935 and 1936, respectively. The Walsh-Healey legislation, enacted in June 1936, mandated minimum wages for all persons employed on federal contracts exceeding $10,000. The act required contractors to pay prevailing minimum wages without deductions, similar to Davis-Bacon. The Walsh-Healey legislation, enacted in June 1936, mandated minimum wages for federal contracts exceeding $10,000. Contractors had to be manufacturers or regular dealers in materials used in the contract. Workhours were limited to 8 hours per day and 40 hours per week. Child labor and convict labor were prohibited, and work had to be done in safe and sanitary conditions to prevent sweatshop production. The Walsh-Healey Act, enacted in June 1936, mandated minimum wages for federal contracts exceeding $10,000 and limited workhours to 8 hours per day and 40 hours per week. The act did not apply to goods available in the open market, agriculture, or common carriers. The Secretary of Labor had the authority to make exceptions if compliance would impair government business and could also debar firms for breaches of the act. The Walsh-Healey Act mandated minimum wages and limited work hours for federal contracts over $10,000. The Secretary of Labor had the authority to make exceptions and debar firms for breaches. The Secretary could allow variations and exemptions, but wage determination methods varied. In 1952, amendments required rate determinations to be made on record after a hearing, with judicial review available for legal questions. Rendering prevailing wage rate determinations under the Walsh-Healey Act posed practical challenges. The Department of Labor had discretion in handling critical concepts like surveying firms, determining payroll periods, and differentiating between employees. The Bureau of Labor Statistics conducted wage surveys for manufacturing establishments to establish a database. When conducting surveys of manufacturing establishments to establish a database, BLS worked under a promise of firm-specific confidentiality. Affected firms only saw general tabulations, not the underlying data, leading to challenges in the validity of the Department's calculations. In the 1964 case of Wirtz v. Baldor Electric Co., the court criticized the Department's wage determination process for lacking transparency and reliable evidence, leading to potential invalidation of determinations under the Walsh-Healey Act. In the aftermath of Wirtz v. Baldor Electric, Walsh-Healey wage rate determinations ceased, making the federal minimum wage the prevailing minimum for Walsh-Healey purposes. The Walsh-Healey Act in 1936 established an 8-hour workday and 40-hour workweek for covered workers, with provisions for overtime pay at one and a half times the basic rate. The Secretary had discretion to adjust these standards, but overtime pay had to be ensured. The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) was signed into law in mid-1938, dropping the daily limit on hours of work but keeping a weekly standard of 40 hours. By the late 1960s, conflicts arose between the overtime pay requirements of Walsh-Healey and the FLSA, leading to calls for greater work scheduling flexibility. Congress later adopted the Federal Employee's Flexible and Compressed Work Schedules Act in 1978. The Federal Employee's Flexible and Compressed Work Schedules Act (P.L. 95-390) allowed federal agencies to schedule work hours over a two-week 80-hour period without overtime pay. Congress later amended Walsh-Healey and the Contract Work Hours and Safety Standards Act to align with the FLSA's 40-hour standard for federal contract work. President Ronald Reagan signed the measure into law on November 8, 1985, addressing concerns about bid brokers in federal procurement. The original Walsh-Healey Act aimed to prevent bid brokers from marketing work to contractors who could do the work cheaply. Eligible contractors had to be manufacturers or regular dealers of the materials specified in the contract, as defined by DOL regulations. During the 103rd Congress, the Walsh-Healey Act was amended to give the Secretary of Labor discretion in determining eligibility criteria for contractors. There was initially confusion over whether naval vessel construction fell under the Davis-Bacon Act or the Walsh-Healey Act, but a change in the law clarified that naval vessels were covered by Walsh-Healey. The repeal of Title 10, Section 7299 in 1994 resulted in marine vessels being subject to the Davis-Bacon Act for contracts exceeding $2,000. Despite objections, the Department of Labor deemed the issue moot, but it was later reinstated in the Fiscal Year 1996 Department of Defense Authorization Act. The Department reinstated former 10 U.S.C. 7299, making naval vessel contracts subject to the PCA [Walsh-Healey]. In the 1960s, gaps in FLSA coverage persisted, especially for service employees. Legislation was proposed in the 88th Congress to extend minimum wage standards to service workers, supported by the Johnson Administration. DOL Solicitor Charles Donahue argued in August 1965 for fair wages for low-paid service industry workers, especially those on government contracts. He highlighted the impact of low-wage rates and lack of labor standards on downward wage trends. The Johnson Administration expressed concerns about the downward spiral of wage rates, emphasizing that low wages were not beneficial for the economy. Charles Donahue emphasized that substandard wages lead to substandard performance and reduced purchasing power. The Pelly-O'Hara bill, aimed at fair wages for low-paid service industry workers, generated little controversy and was passed by the House and Senate. The McNamara-O'Hara Service Contract Act, passed in 1965, closed a gap in labor standards protection for federal contract workers. It requires certain labor standards provisions in contracts exceeding $2,500 for services in the U.S., including a minimum wage determined by the Secretary. The McNamara-O'Hara Service Contract Act of 1965 established labor standards for federal contract workers, ensuring they are paid at least the minimum wage set by the FLSA, provided with fringe benefits, and work in safe conditions. Service employees under the act include guards, watchmen, skilled and unskilled laborers, and supervisors with trade or laboring experience. The Service Contract Act (SCA) was amended in 1972 and 1976 to expand coverage, improve administrative efficiency, enforce the act, and encourage stability in the service industry. The amendments focused on defining terms of coverage due to complications arising from imprecise definitions. Some Members of Congress expressed concerns about the implementation of the statute, leading to the legislation (P.L. 92-473) being revised to benefit service workers and employers. The Service Contract Act (SCA) was amended in 1972 and 1976 to provide flexibility and allow the Secretary to develop a suitable wage rate determination methodology. Congress amended the act to require wage rate determinations for progressively smaller contracts after July 1, 1976. After July 1, 1976, contracts for more than five service employees were required to be made. In service contracts, labor cost competitiveness led to lower wages and benefits, resulting in a lack of continuity and stability in the industry. This wage-based competition created a downward spiral with cheaper, less competent workers being hired annually, impacting the quality of services provided. The annual rotation of contractors led to a focus on short-term profits over quality of performance, potentially burdening the community with low-paid service workers. The requirement for successor contractors to pay wages and benefits at least equal to those in the predecessor contract was contentious. The provision in service contracts was seen as favoring workers and potentially removing wages from competitive mix. Concerns were raised about federal employees being disadvantaged through contracting out. Congress added language to ensure comparability in rates for service employees. Service contracts could be negotiated for up to five years. Interpretive questions continued after the 1972 amendments. Interpretive questions arose after the 1972 amendments to the Service Contract Act regarding coverage and definitions. There were concerns about whether white-collar and technical workers were included, leading to disputes between agencies, industry, and labor. Congress held hearings in 1974-1976 to clarify coverage, with the House Subcommittee intending to include white-collar workers under the SCA. The 1976 amendments to the Service Contract Act clarified coverage but left some definitional issues unresolved, such as the exemption of contract workers involved in technical services. The Secretary of Labor deemed these exemptions necessary for the public interest. Other issues, like the concept of principal purpose and the status of service employees under certain contracts, remained contentious. After the 1976 amendments to the Service Contract Act, further refinement of the act was left to administrative rulemaking, litigation, and procurement reform initiatives. The Davis-Bacon Act has been the most controversial of the three related statutes, with strong interest groups both defending and opposing it. The prevailing wage provisions of the Davis-Bacon Act have been a focus of attention and sparked controversy. The Davis-Bacon Act, along with other related statutes, has had a significant impact on various program statutes, expanding its reach to different groups unfamiliar with its requirements. While the McNamara-O'Hara Act faced contention in the past, it has largely disappeared from legislative agendas. The Walsh-Healey Act, although moderately controversial in the past, has been overshadowed by other more contentious New Deal statutes. The Davis-Bacon Act, enacted in 1931, set minimum wage and overtime standards co-equal to the Fair Labor Standards Act. It influenced the Walsh-Healey Act, which Congress passed in 1936 as a consumer protection measure. The Supreme Court's shift in attitude towards labor standards for the private sector paved the way for the FLSA in 1938. Congress focused on the shortcomings of the National Industrial Recovery Act during the FLSA's consideration. The demise of the NIRA highlighted court acceptance of labor standards. Congress expanded wage/hour legislation beyond Davis-Bacon and Walsh-Healey with the FLSA. The FLSA gradually extended coverage to more workers, with amendments in 1961 and 1966 adding millions of workers, especially in the service sector. Congress established wage/hour standards for federal workers. By the late 20th century, two separate federal wage/hour structures had been developed. The FLSA provided minimum wage and overtime pay protections for most workers, while construction and service workers on federal contracts had super-minimum wage protections under the Davis-Bacon and McNamara-O'Hara Acts. Additionally, workers producing goods for the federal government were required to be paid at least the locally prevailing minimum wage under the Walsh-Healey Act. The Contract Work Hours and Safety Standards Act (1969) provided overtime pay protection for construction and service workers, initially more protective than the FLSA. Congress modified the provisions of these statutes over the years, attempting to resolve administrative issues. Despite efforts to simplify, problems continued to arise, leading to demands for revision or repeal of the statutes. Establishing the minimum wage under the FLSA was relatively straightforward, with Congress mandating a national wage floor after conducting hearings. Congress mandated a national wage floor, leaving little discretion to the Secretary of Labor. Prevailing wage rates, such as Davis-Bacon and Walsh-Healey, were not clearly defined in statutes, creating challenges for calculation. Various qualifiers had to be considered by the Department, adding complexity to the process. The Secretary was directed to consider rates for service employees in relation to direct federal workers, with a fringe benefit component included. Rates for Davis-Bacon and McNamara-O'Hara were to be associated with specific crafts or types of work, despite job title standardization issues. The concept of "locality" was clearer for Davis-Bacon, especially when workers with specific skills were not locally available. The Department and contractors might need to look to adjoining jurisdictions for workforce recruitment. Recruiting a workforce under the Walsh-Healey Act posed challenges due to the uncertainty of production locations and the involvement of components from various jurisdictions. The concept of locality for wage rate determination purposes was ambiguous, with the Secretary often opting for nationwide or industrywide determinations instead of using "groups of industries currently operating in the locality." A variety of geographical standards may apply to government procurement bids and contracts, with wage rates for federal contract workers being determined by various labor standards such as Davis-Bacon, Walsh-Healey, and McNamara-O'Hara Acts. The Contract Work Hours and Safety Standards Act (CWHSSA) supplements labor standards for federal contract workers, including the Davis-Bacon Act and the McNamara-O'Hara Act. Employers engaged in federal contract work are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Act and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), which sets minimum wages, overtime pay rates, and restricts child labor and industrial homework. State labor standards may also apply, especially in cases of mixed state and federal funding. Additionally, municipal "living wage" laws have emerged as a new body of wage regulations. The "living wage" laws set minimum wage and standards for contractors working with local government units. These laws, along with federal contract labor standards statutes and the FLSA, aim to protect workers and stabilize the workplace. The statutes have evolved over time, with some arguing for updates to make enforcement easier and more effective. The need to update labor standards laws is being questioned, with concerns about maintaining protections while modernizing. There is debate over potential consolidation of statutes to simplify enforcement and make them more worker-friendly.
